explanation: The report is correct. The memchr(name_ptr, 0, OS_MAX_FILE_NAME) call can cause memchr to scan up to OS_MAX_FILE_NAME bytes starting at name_ptr without ensuring that that many bytes are actually part of the VirtualPath object. Although OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN) ensures the overall string has a terminating NUL within OS_MAX_PATH_LEN bytes from the start, it does not guarantee that there are OS_MAX_FILE_NAME bytes available from the name_ptr position to the end of the underlying object. If name_ptr points near the end of the VirtualPath object (or if the caller provided a smaller buffer), memchr may access bytes beyond the object, which violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. (A safe fix is to limit the memchr length to the actual remaining bytes from name_ptr to the known string terminator/object end, e.g. compute the remaining length and use the minimum of that and OS_MAX_FILE_NAME.)
